question: Know what the problem is, kid? You're too ugly to get propositioned.
C'mon, it's a quiet night. Next week we work the park.
answer: I gotta get back on top. Get off the sleaze detail.

question: So what'll you do? After they give you the gold watch.
answer: Hell, I got a gold watch... it just don't work. Maybe they'll give me a new fishing pole, or something useful.

question: You don't fish.
answer: How hard can it be? The grand kids been buggin' me about taking them camping.

question: You outta the city... that's a fish out of water. What's with all this family talk lately, anyway?
answer: One of these days you're gonna get tired of fighting the shit. When that happens, you'll wish you had family.

question: No thanks. I got close but it never woulda worked.
answer: Why don't you just shoot it and put it out of its misery?

question: What are you talking about, it's purring like a kitty.
answer: I thought you said what's-her-name's brother was going to fix it.

question: She didn't work out, had to cut her loose.
She wanted to cook me breakfast.
answer: We're vice, I didn't see no pimps or hookers in that van. But if you're so gung-ho, we'd best call it in for some back-up.

question: Nah, let's just take a look-see. Ow! Son-of-a-bitch.
Yeah, just a nick ...
Mike...
Take your time... one day at a time, kid...
May I help you?
answer: I'm looking for the Bomb Squad.

question: They're not here.
And you are...?
There out on a call, perhaps I can help you-
2600 block of Lakefront. A limousine. But, I-
Schnoz says it's loaded. Good boy, Schnozzie.
answer: Alright boys, look close. Let's assess.

question: Whadaya think, "boy" or "girl"?
Look, it's important. It's about this.
Off a girl's wrist. A suspect... What?
answer: High-grade det cord. This girl, either she's got strange taste in jewelry or she's into serious demolition.

question: We can't take the chance. Ring down to the Bomb Squad. I want them on alert.
Goddamit, Reilly--
answer: Look, I saw these guys, I can i.d. them.

question: I know you're anxious to get back but... just stay out of homicide's way or I'll have you classifying fingerprints, understand?
What was-? Why...?
answer: That cop who bought it... you didn't tell us he was your partner. Let's get something straight. We're doing you a favor. You're not exactly a guy we want around explosives.

question: What?
answer: This isn't bumper cars, it's brain surgery. You wanna work with us, you do it our way, understand?

question: Now wait just a fucking-
answer: Be cool around my men, they don't trust strangers. And try not to swear so much, it's unattractive. By the way, I'm Glass. This is T.J., and Pooch.

question: What kind of bomb was it? Huh?
answer: We don't use the b-word. Bad luck.

question: So you're the "Device Squad"... and you defuse "devices"?
Anything else I should know?
Don't push it, slick.
answer: I don't know... Good boy, Schnoz. Daddy loves you.

question: C4, plastic explosive.
Where's the girl? The one I brought in.
answer: Tough? Tough is "Fuck you, where's my lawyer?". This chick doesn't say boo.

question: Any luck?
Captain said I could give it a crack.
answer: She ain't no hooker. This is a murder investigation.

question: She was my collar. Maybe I'll get lucky. But, if you got a problem with that, talk to the Captain.
We missed you, where'd you go? Awright! How bout you, Glass, how's that chip shaking?
answer: I was wrong... this didn't come from any cash register.

question: Whadaya mean?
A what?
answer: I.R.A. device. Deadliest class of tickers in existence. Computerized, multiple sensors, booby traps, the works. First showed up in a series of I.R.A. bombings in London couple years ago. One of their boys tripped it on himself and they went back to a less complicated timers. The Girl, is she Irish?

question: She's not talking. But, she could be. So, obviously, you've seen one of these devices before?
All of you, shut the fuck up!
answer: Nice performance back there. Where'd you learn that, Mike Ditka Sensitivity Seminar?

question: Hey, look--
answer: No you look, mister! First, you don't go calling my men names. It's bad for morale. Second, us "punks" happen to know a heck of alot more about police work than any vice cop ever did.

question: Oh yeah? Prove it.
The place has already be combed. Forensics pulled over a hundred sets of prints inside.
answer: Then let's go see what they missed. So what were they doing here?

question: I don't know. You tell me?
answer: An abandoned machine shop... nice place to build devices. Low rent, too. But, you and Rice ruined their perfect hideout.

question: You mentioned something called Redstone.
answer: Redstone's the army training center in Alabama where they send the cream of the crop to learn about tickers.

question: Cream of the crop, huh? You?
answer: Top of my class at West Point, thank you very much. Then off to Redstone. First half of the course we learned how to build devices... second half, we'd take them apart. Everything from firecrackers to hydrogen bombs.

question: Sounds like terrorist heaven.
answer: There were a few guys in my class with names like John Smith, Bill Jones. I'd see them up ahead in the hall, call their name, but they wouldn't turn around. C.I.A. Funny thing, they'd always disappear after the first half of the course.

question: Just how easy is it to build a... device?
answer: With a little training, you could go into a house and just from stuff in the bathroom and kitchen make something that'd finish off that alleged car of yours. Heck, didn't you ever watch MacGyver?

question: Girl was here. The guy in charge was over there with one of his men, the other one was back there.
answer: Typical profile, usually losers, nobodies that're afraid to confront their victims. They like scaring people. That's why they call in their threats. Same mentality as obscene phone callers.

question: Except they'll blow you up if you don't play along.
answer: No, ninety-ninety percent of them are full of baloney. They're into the power trip, not the damage. What scares me is that this guy is so sophisticated he could blow up whatever he wants, then disappear. The worst of the bunch, they love the challenge of creating the wildest device ever... and they love the carnage. This is where the van was parked.

question: Yep.
answer: Then, it's gotta be here somewhere ...

question: Look, it's a longshot...
Nitro-cellulose. What is that, some kind of explosive?
answer: Industrial wood oil. Separately, any one of these things could lead in several directions, but together ...

question: Still waiting for a miracle. Go ahead.
answer: It's a small fraternity, everyone knows everyone. I'm always recruiting. Pooch is ex- D.O.D., military expert... claymores, grenades. He played linebacker at Boston College, worked a K-9 unit - that led him to the Bomb Squad... great nose, lousy fingers, we try to keep him away from the tickers. T.J. is a heck of chemist, Texas A&M engineering degree. Found him in a Militia chat room - turns out we were both monitoring the same groups. Bev is the natural born hacker, we stole her from dispatch. She had the Cave reorganized and ultra-high-tech in two months. Captain has no idea how much hardware she's "found" for us.

question: You guys seem pretty tight.
answer: We've gotta be. In this business, you don't exactly make alot of outside commitments.

question: Why do you do it?
answer: I don't know, it's strange... it's not the best career path, but when you get the bug, there's nothing you can do about it. See, when you beat one of these things...

question: Looks like Pooch's doing okay. There he goes. He was here the whole time. Say, thanks for the back up--
You heard him, get the fuck away, it's a bomb!
Okay, I'm going in, nobody breathe.
One shuts it down, one turns arms it.
I don't know. There's an old saying, when in doubt, cut the yellow wire.
Is this a great job or what?
What's this?
answer: Report on the case so far.

question: You know after a shooting I would normally take your badge and weapon, but Glass called in already and confirmed it was clean.
`Night...
What?
answer: You don't have to talk about it.

question: Pittsburgh, two years ago. Partner died, no back-up, I was too gung-ho. As usual.
answer: Take a tip from the Bomb Boys, always assess, if only for a second.

question: I know. I was working a drug ring, deep cover. Played the part too well. When they pulled me out, I wasn't a cop anymore. My fiance had dumped me. Next thing I knew, I was out here on the street, doped up, auditioning for the morgue when this tough old vice cop found me, cleaned me up, gave me a second chance. He promised Captain Winters he'd look out for me.
I guess I didn't realize how much I needed him. He kept me straight. It's been tough every second since.
I terrible with mechanical things.
answer: No you're not, you just don't understand them. Here, do what I tell you.

question: It's working.
answer: Congratulations, you just built your first ticker.

question: Okay, hit it.
Don't bet on it. How's the print coming?
answer: One partial from the handle matches the suspect from last night. Name's Carl Taylor. Long record of arson, assault, the works. The other print - we got nothing from our data base or the FBI or CIA... still waiting for Interpol.

question: Damn.
No thanks, Bev.
answer: Yes, sir. He's here. I'll tell him.

question: Yes ... no, of course not but ... yes, sir, I understand.
She's refused to say a word to anyone. What made you think you could get her to talk?
answer: I didn't. But I had to try. Yes, sir.

question: I read your report. Impressive. I'd say it's got detective written all over it. But... you cross the line one more time... you're gone. Are we clear?
Hello. But they weren't all insured.
answer: Cover. It was suppose to be abandoned buildings, y'know. No one was suppose to get hurt. The night you busted us...We were checking to make sure there weren't any vagrants around. Scare them away.

question: Who is he?
answer: Alex Swan. My brother. The other two are called Taylor and Leveau.

question: Taylor's dead.
answer: There is a motel downtown, near the Machine Shop... the Suncrest. Room 138.

question: Thank you.
Then why tell me?
Be right back.
No, of course not... well, thanks anyway. Here you go, Your Highness.
answer: On second thought, maybe I did. Lemme see... yeah, here it is, 11:18 this morning. Very disrespectful. He used to drive a van, but he got a new car. You want the license number?

question: Glass, sorry about Pooch, he was a good man. We don't have time to give you a break right now, we're going ahead and-
answer: My God, you're going to use her, aren't you?

question: Glass, you're to stand by with your team.
answer: I promised her she'd be safe.

question: It's our only option.
answer: It won't work, he'll know it's a trap...

question: Reilly, you're done for now. What the hell were you thinking directing the Bomb Squad Team into hot pursuit. They had no business-
You've been at the center of two suspect fatalities and two Police Officer fatalities. I'll need your badge and your weapon.
Winters here.
answer: You motherfuckers, you don't learn, do you?!

question: We're prepared to talk-
answer: Shut up! Shut up! You have exactly thirty minutes to release the girl where you found her. Thirty minutes.

question: You okay?
I know. I warned them.
Security. You hungry? We could get something to eat. What's the matter?
answer: Nothing... just tired. Why are we stopping here?

question: We're moving' on. I have to pick up the supplies. Just two little boxes.
Stay here.
Stay in the truck.
answer: Get me the police! Yes! Please, hurry! Please, I need help, my name is--

question: Who are you calling, sis?
Shut up! Who is this?
C'mon, move it. Dispatch, this is Reilly. Patch me through to the Bomb Squad. Just do it. T.J., it's Reilly, put Glass on!
Where you guys at?
Catch that alert? That's him in the U-Haul.
Cuz he got the girl, now he's leaving town.
answer: Should we head for the Interstate?

question: Would you?
answer: No, I'd slip out past the hotel district, behind Greyhound...

question: Me, too. Glass, Eighth Street, alley behind Grand Hotel. Cut him off. All units, suspect spotted heading down alley behind Grand Hotel.
answer: Reilly, what the hell are you-?

question: Fire me later. Close in and we got the bastard.
answer: Pull back. You're only an observer. Reilly, what's happening? Reilly! Reilly! Do not engage. We're five minutes-

question: Hold on to that thing tight.
Off the scale.
Can you hold it?
Right.
answer: C'mon, talk to me! We can do it!

question: He has a timer going as back-up, in case we got a hold of the remote. Okay... first, run your fingers along the edges, feel for a sensor. Good, now the other side.
Okay, let's go in.
Close your eyes, feel your fingertips. Tell me everything you feel.
Don't touch that.
Stay to your left.
That's the blasting cap - good! Okay, now grab it by the base and pull it straight up. No, Wait...
Too easy. There's gotta be something else in there, another cap maybe.
Ease your thumb over to the right - feel anything?
Okay, one of the caps turns it on, the other shuts it down.
I don't know.
When in doubt, pull the yellow wire.
answer: How the hell do you feel yellow?

question: No excuses, just do it!
